haiku: Room full of people / and nary a word to be said / because I'm the temp.
Opening your heart / bids the possibility / of much agony.
Don't hate me for me / but for what I do to you / when I'm being me.
Sounds of a scuffle. / Soft whimpers in the darkness. / Don't play the hero.
If I could only / say one nice thing about me / with no 'but' after.
A cold, windy night. / I offer her my sweater / many sizes too large.
If this does not work, / this will be the last I try. / To all a goodbye.
All I really want / is for you to say nice things / and only to me.
All I have written / may not be deemed a haiku; / yet I continue.
I know sad moments / are such when happy moments / must take a short rest.
Counting syllables / is easy as a human / but not a machine.
Your words inflict pain / but not as much those moments / when you say nothing.
It is not the kiss / but in the moment before, / when our eyes decide.
I wish I could be / all that you need me to be / but also be fun.
Put pen to paper / for words imply honesty / without a backspace.
As she walks away / she can't help but turn her head / and sees that he hasn't.
The silence scares him. / If he were to stop talking. / they'd stop listening.
How many meat pies / does it take for you to stop / hating who you are.
Playing with words is / so much fun when there's no one / around to hear it.
Sits perched on the edge / with lips ajar, waiting for / when someone will hear.
description:
How does one interject?
Sometimes you want to say something but you don't want to come off as rude.
Sometimes you say something but maybe it's not loud enough.

Or maybe it is?

haiku: There's nothing quite as / dead as the dried husk of a / gas station sandwich.
description:
It's 2am and I'm hungry.
Looks like the only thing that's open is a local gas station.
The sandwiches are warm, bathed in a harsh fluorescent white.
I could have gone for the meatpies but I was on a health kick and a sandwich is just a tad healthier. Less carbs.

All cardboard.

haiku: Her arms extended / Is she playing an airplane? / Oh, she wants a hug!
description:
It's embarrasing to think, with arms wide open, I never considered she wanted a hug?
What does that say about me?

Am I so terrified of human contact and intimacy that the thought of a hug is the furthest from my mind?.

No, she always could make me fly.

haiku: Just keep your head up / look forward and don't falter / your neck will thank you.
description:
Turns out I can write a positive message.

All it took was a neck injury.

haiku: An end to this job / This raccoon sheds her burden / New horizons bloom.
description:
I wrote this for a friend, of mutual raccoon interest. 
We bonded over the joys and pains of work.

An unlikely relationship that helped transform the worst of times.
But we must all move on. 
 
Even a raccoon finds a new dumpster.

I mean job.

haiku: I need an A.I. / Wisdom woven in circuits / I did not write that.
description:
Yea, ChatGPT ain't too bad at writing Haikus. 
They're almost too good though. 
No one would believe I wrote this.
In a world of too good, I want to stand out as an outlier.

I'm too bad.

haiku: Sitting in a van / With cheese my sustenance / I write my tall tales.
description:
A French girl made me think of cheese recently. 
Another not French girl made me think of road trips. 

I've discovered girls make me think a lot and thinking a lot makes me want to write a lot.

Wouldn't it be fun to write a lot in a van? 
With cheese?

I think so.

haiku: Long prose, standing still / The words are hard to come by / Substack posts are none.
description:
Gosh, I wish I could write longer form content. 
But I question myself on every line. 
Haikus are equal parts easy and hard. 

But the constraints give me, ironically, more freedom. 
Freedom to be free from my own mind because the haiku is done. 

It only took three lines and a lot of finger counting.

haiku: Van life, open road / Dastardly deeds, no one sees / Haikus guide my dream.
description:
I was told my haikus have the power to manifest reality. I'm not sure if that's true but I'm going to try it out. 

Sadly, I don't own a valid license, nor a valid van. But I do have a strange reader who is the type to throw caution to the wind.

I hope this doesn't work.

haiku: Paths fork and divide / Each step, maybe a misstep? / Best a step than none.
description:
Sometimes its easier when the possibilities aren't endless.
You know just what step to take. Just what offer to take. Just the right hand to shake.

But as the nearing clock of time clicks, the possibilities still remain, forever endless.
And I am left to ponder: Is this the last fork from which I can't return?

My energy is limited and I can't afford to waste it. 

But I can't afford to waste it.

haiku: Pixels on a screen / Jira tickets left unseen / I am so fucking bored.
description:
There's nothing left to interpretation on this one.

When did writing a function, pushing a pixel and wrangling dotfiles start becoming so mundane?
Should work be fun or just a vehicle for fun?

Should programming be fun or just afford me the pleasures of a good income?

I paid for my fries and shake with a conditional.

haiku: If I had a cat / Moonlit eyes and gentle steps / Would that be enough?
description:
If I had a cat...

On a cold lonely day
When the sun don't shine.
And it's too wet to stray.
Could I sit in the house?
And hear it purr all that cold, cold, wet day


Probably.
